title-group.article-title: Description of the final stadium larva of Anisopleura furcata Selys, 1891 (Odonata: Euphaeidae) from Thailand

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Description of the final stadium larva of
Anisopleura furcata Selys, 1891
( Odonata : Euphaeidae ) from Thailand

TOSAPHOL SAETUNG KEETAPITHCHAYAKUL 1* , ALBERT G. ORR 2 & KORAON WONGKAMHAENG 3* 1 The Center for Entomology &
Parasitology Research, College of Medicine and Pharmacy, Duy Tan University, 120 Hoang Minh Thao, Lien Chieu, Da Nang , Vietnam .
Ễ Keetapithchayakul.TS@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7565-4701

2
Environmental Futures Research Institute, Griffith University, Nathan, Australia .
Ễ agorr@bigpond.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3699-2745

3 Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Kasetsart University, 50 Ngam Wong Wan Rd, Lat Yao, Chatuchak, Bangkok , Thailand .
Ễ
Koraon@gmail.com ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-7671-8869
*Corresponding authors

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
The final stadium larva of
Anisopleura furcata Selys, 1891
is described and illustrated. The larva can be separated from all known
Anisopleura Selys, 1853
larvae by the following characters: the profusion of elongated tubercles on the labrum and antefrons, the presence of a long bifid spur on the outer margin of the mandibles, presence of a row of claviform setae on dorsal apex of tarsus, and antennae 8-segmented. The inner lobe of the labial palps forms a tiny truncate tooth broadly similar to the condition in all other known members of the genus. Diagnostic features that separate this species from potentially syntopic euphaeid genera are discussed.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words:
Anisopleura
,
Euphaeidae
, larval description ,
Chiang Mai
,
Thailand

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The euphaeid genus
Anisopleura Selys, 1853
includes 11 species listed in Paulson et al . (2024) distributed throughout Thailand , Indochina, southern China , northern India and the Himalayan states, where they typically inhabit clear, upland, forested streams above ca 1000m . Four
Anisopleura
have been recorded in Thailand ; A.
furcata Selys, 1891
,
A. pelecyphora Zhang, Hämäläinen & Cai, 2014
,
A. subplatystyla Fraser, 1927
from the north, and
A. trulla Hämäläinen, 2003
from the south. At present, knowledge of the larval stage of the genus
Anisopleura
, and indeed the family Euphaeidae Yakobson & Bianchi, 1905 overall is limited (
;
). Existing larval descriptions of
Anisopleura
lack comprehensive diagnostic characters, with only three species—
A. comes Hagen, 1880
,
A. subplatystyla
and
A. lestoides Selys, 1853
—having been described and illustrated (
;
;
, respectively).

In this study, we provide a comprehensive description of the larval stage of
A. furcata
from northern Thailand . Additionally, we compare the morphological characteristics of this larva with those of the three above
Anisopleura
larvae and discuss relationships with the known larvae of other euphaeid genera, especially those which may occur syntopically with
Anisopleura
.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Larvae were collected from riffles in a headwater stream in Doi Inthanon National Park and other unprotected sites. Permission was granted by the Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation, Thailand for collecting aquatic insects. The last stadium larvae were transferred to the laboratory for rearing in earthenware pots connected to an oxygen pump until the emergence of adults. The larvae were fed with chironomid larvae and amphipods. Pebbles were provided as a substrate (see
). The species identification of the adult was based on
. Measurements and photographs were taken using a ZEISS Stemi 508 stereomicroscope with OPTIKA C-P6 Digital Camera. All illustrations were made using the Procreate application on an iPad Pro 2020 device and were based on a representative digital photograph. The final plates were prepared using Adobe Photoshop CC 2017. The description of larval mandibular formulas follows
. The characteristic surface structures on the integument of the larva, such as spines, setae, and tubercles are shown ( Fig. 1 ), with the following acronyms formulated for convenience: simple setae, SS; spatulate setae, SLS; claviform setae, CVS; spiniform setae, SPS; tubercle with small setae TWS. Other abbreviations used were: Abdominal segments 1–10, S1–S10; antennomeres 1–8, A1–A8; where A1 is the scape, and A2 the pedicel. The specimens have been placed in the private collections of T.S. Keetapithchayakul and A.G. Orr.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Description of the larva of
Anisopleura furcata Selys, 1891

Description of larva. Habitus elongate with long robust legs with broad flattened femora, abdomen semi– cylindrical, tapered caudad, with seven pairs of ventral gills, anal gills saccoid, elongate and gradually tapering; coloration variable, yellowish-brown to brownish-black; front of head with conspicuous tubercles ( Fig. 2 ).

Measurements. (in mm; n = 10 (5 F-0, 3 F-1 alcohol preserved specimens and 2 exuviae); Minimum–Maximum [mean]: total length of body without caudal gills = 13.59–18.68 [16.72]; length of caudal gills (median: lateral) = 9.09–9.95 [9.48]: 7.96–9.74 [8.93]; width and length of head = 2.785 –3.165 [2.99] and 3.15–3.36 [3.27]; length of antenna = 1.76–2.09 [1.96]; maximum width and length of prementum = 2.59–3.06 [2.87] and 3.33–3.5 [3.39]; length of movable hook = 0.82–0.90 [0.87]; length of inner and outer wing pads = 5.7–6.63 [6.28] and 5.41–6.16 [5.89]; length of femora (fore: mid: hind) = 2.15–3.06 [2.83]: 3.45–3.66 [3.56]: 4.4–4.75 [4.59]; length of tibiae (fore: mid: hind) = 2.6–3.88 [3.26]: 2.55–4.07 [3.41]: 3.26–4.52 [4.07].

sec.title: Biological notes
sec.p:
The larvae of
A. furcata
inhabit small clear streams in open habitats surrounded by trees, herbs, and shrubs and also in dense primary forest. The composition of the habitat on Doi Inthanon was as follows: pebble/gravel/sand/silt (45%), small stones (30%), leaf litter (10%), aquatic plants (5%), large rocks (4%), and large boulders (1%) ( Fig. 8 ). The habitats where AGO collected his specimens were both smaller clear streams with a mainly rocky substrate, and gently flowing riffles; the larvae were located under mossy rocks and stones 20–30 cm diameter. Doi Suthep was heavily forested, and very close to the source of the stream; Mae Tong Luang was downstream a little from the source in a shaded area where the riparian flora was still largely intact, despite extensive clearing upstream and in the surrounds.

They cling to the substrate, often upside down, under stones and pebbles in riffles ( Fig. 9 ) and may be found together with larvae of the genus
Euphaea Selys, 1840
. Some specimens had chironomid larva attached in their abdominal gills in a phoretic association (
).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Besides the larva of
A. furcata
, another three larvae of the genus
Anisopleura
have been illustrated and/or described.
briefly described
A. comes
illustrating the larval habitus, and the labial palp;
A . subplatystyla
was illustrated only by the larval habitus and prementum with sketchy labial palps (
) and
A. lestoides
was described in some detail by
. It should be noted that while Fraser unaccountably stated that the larva bore no abdominal gills, the illustrations he provided were probably quite accurate.

The larva of
A. furcata
can be separated from the other three species by a combination of characteristics, especially the profusion of elongated tubercles on the labrum and antefrons (short tubercles are probably present to some extent in
A. comes
, and unidentified specimens examined by AGO from the Himalayas suggest they are probably present but very much shorter in
A. lestoides
and
A. subplatystyla
), the presence of a bifid spur on the outer margin of the mandibles (single spur:
A . lestoides
, single spur suggested:
A. comes
and
A. subplatystyla
), presence of row of CVS on distal end of A1 (probably absent:
A. lestoides
, no information:
A. comes
and
A. subplatystyla
), inner lobe of labial palps forming tiny truncate tooth (tiny truncate tooth:
A. comes
; short but well defined tooth:
A. lestoides
, no information:
A. subplatystyla
). There exists an anonymous photograph of another
Anisopleura species
, taken in southern Vietnam and viewed by AGO, that based on location is most probably
A. bipungio Hämäläinen & Karube, 2013
(M. Hämäläinen pers comm.). This larva is very like that of
A. furcata
with which it is closely related (M. Hämäläinen pers comm.). It also has long tubercles on the frons and labrum but three spurs on the outer mandible and the antennae are 7-segmented.

Superficially,
A. furcata
is immediately separated from any known congeners by virtue of the elongated tubercles on labrum and antefrons. Although previous descriptions and illustrations of other
Anisopleura species
were lacking in fine detail from
A . lestoides
and
A . subplatystyla
, at least,
A. comes
shows smaller tubercles in the habitus drawing. It seems inconceivable that such a prominent character could have passed unnoticed by any of these authors, but low or sparse button-like tubercles would not have been recorded.

All
Anisopleura
larvae bear a resemblance to the known larvae of other genera within the family Euphaeidae , including
Bayadera Selys, 1853
, and
Euphaea
with which they may co-occur. These genera all have the definitive synapomorphy for the family, the presence of abdominal gills on S2–S8, and also share characters such as saccoid gills, stout build and, usually, a subocular row of spines on the genae, all of which, however, also occur in other ‘calopterygoid’ families, sensu
. A less obvious, possible synapomorphy for Euphaeidae may be the presence of claviform setae, first noted by
in
Euphaea refulgens Hagen
in Selys, 1853, which they surmised had a sensory function.

The diagnostic characteristics of
Anisopleura
distinguishing it from the genera
Bayadera
and
Euphaea
are as follows: 1) very shallow posterior lobes with sinuous posterior margin where it meets the rear margin of the occiput forming a sharp posterior angle (deep without sinous margin:
Bayadera
/
Euphaea
), 2) antenna shorter than head from rear margin of occiput to base of labrum (at least as long as or longer in
Bayadera
/
Euphaea
) and 3) well developed but acute male gonapophyses (poorly developed:
Euphaea
; large and sausage shaped
Bayadera
) (
;
;
,
). Information on larval characters in the family Euphaeidae is at present not well resolved. In some cases, specimens are available, but identity is not confirmed. Many previous descriptions have mostly been done on an ad hoc basis, without proper reference to congeners or other genera, often simply because this information did not exist, and older (and recent) literature is either lacking in detail or inaccurate, or both, leading to some confusion regarding the significance of diagnostic characters (
). There is a range of potential diagnostic characters such as the shape of the postocular lobe, gonapophyses, perhaps the arrangement of subocular spines along margin of the genae, armature of postocular lobe, and the shape of the caudal gills. The presence/absence and arrangement of setae in various situations and the presence of prothoracic coxal spines and supracoxal armature may also be significant.

To characterise the larvae of the family Euphaeidae a concentrated effort to thoroughly assess these features is needed in order to assess their diagnostic status in each species or genus. For this, good series of verified specimens are needed. At present the larvae for three genera in the family (
Cyclophaea Ris, 1930
,
Schmidtiphaea Asahina, 1978
, and
Cryptophaea Hämäläinen, 2003
) are completely unknown. Therefore, further study should be aimed at concentrated fieldwork to obtain the much needed specimens, as well as rearing and/or DNA matching with adults to ensure reliable determinations, rather than supposition. With habitats contracting at an alarming rate, and already members of the family judged as endangered, the need for this basic groundwork has never been so pressing.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
The project was partially supported by the Basic Research Fund (BRF 6/2565) from the Faculty of Science , Kasetsart University and the International Dragonfly Fund. We are most grateful to Department of National Parks , Wildlife and Plant Conservation, Thailand for permission to collect specimens in Doi Inthanon National Park . We also thank Dr Vincent Kalkman for his kindness in taking and sharing photographs of Bhutanese specimens specifically to aid this investigation. We would like to extend our gratitude to the two reviewers and the editor (Mr Stephen Butler, Dr Rodolfo Novelo-Gutiérrez, and Dr Milen Marinov), gave constructive comments and improved the final manuscript; Mr Noppadon Makbun and Dr Patchara Danaisawadi for their kind assistance providing comments and advice for this study. We would also like to thank The Center for Entomology & Parasitology Research , College of Medicine and Pharmacy, Duy Tan University and the Department of Zoology , Faculty of Science , Kasetsart University for providing facilities. Albert Orr thanks the late Bro. Amnuay Pinratana ( St. Gabriel's College , Bangkok ) for his generous hospitality and logistic support, and the Brothers of St. Gabriel at Montfort College in Chiang Mai for their kind hospitality in 2003, and to Dr Matti Hämäläinen for his guidance and companionship in the field, as well as helpful recent discussion
.
